review:
I have spent a bit of time sucking blood in this game. V-Rising is a aesthetically stunning game that puts you in the cold flesh of a vampire that must explore the world, craft items, build a castle and slaughter masses to become the most powerful predator in the land.
The game offers a good mix of game play mechanics and immersive environments/ biomes. The game starts of with a basic tutorial giving you the tools you need for basic survival. The game is easy to pick up and learn but it can be difficult to master.
The game is quite absent of a story but the stronger enemies or 'V-Bloods' have interesting information about them that makes slaying them so much more satisfactory.
The game is filled with dangers, beautiful environments, fantasy beasts, in depth crafting options, day and night cycle and more.
If you jump onto a PVP server, prepare to fight players who can be deceptive and down right evil, playing right into the most powerful vampire lord on the server. This may put a few people off the game, but you can also make great friends and allies, band together, then raid the crap out of the enemy.
Most of the player base is waiting for the next content drop which should be soon. This game has so much potential and hopefully the developers will continue to add more and more.

I give the game a 8 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166465907', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 15224, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 1177, 'playtime_at_review': 14586, 'last_played': 1684475814}
review:
(OPEN THE THREAD TO SEE THE FULL REVIEW]

I was hesitant to delve into the V-Rising world as Battlerite is one of my all time favorite video games, and seeing how that was ultimately serviced, I was hesitant to pick up another SLS title. I will section this review off so you may skip around as you please.

Gameplay: 

From the moment I booted up the game, I could tell that SLS was serious about maintaining the aesthetic of their combat system throughout their titles, including V Rising. The combat in the vanilla game, and at the time of this review, more so in the Gloomrot beta, the combat feels clean, and very smooth. The interactions that you have with your abilities, as well as your combo potential all feel very natural and fluid. Pairing this with their WASD movement preference, and generous key-mapping options, the player is ultimately left feeling very comfortable, allowing for them to quickly start mastering the combat system. 

The depth of the combat, like BLC (Bloodline Champions), and Battlerite, has an incredibly high skill ceiling. Between learning your loadout rotations, mastering cancels, improving your aim, honing your CD temperament, and more, you will be left feeling satisfied for what feels like ever. And that is the absolute highest compliment I can give this game. It doesn't matter how good you are mechanically, or strategically, the game is rich and complex enough to offer anyone a challenge.

The day/night cycle is a nice addition to an open world survival game. Often times keeping the player on their toes, and keeping them aware of the time. I think I speak for every player when I say you can FEEL THE HEAT. The sun doesn't discriminate. If you're not pathing carefully, and staying alert, you will be crushed by the sun. The game is often times very fair with the sun placement, with the exception of a few areas feeling like genuine day-time traps. But given the design philosophy, you know, vampires and all, that seems fair. 
The addition of the sun can also impact combat, in both a fun, and sometimes frustrating way. It can be difficult to ascertain whether or not a boss or pack of mobs is doable given movement restrictions in some areas due to the sun. But often times, skilled players can maneuver with the shade, adapting quickly to complex situations regarding movement, which ultimately makes it fun in my opinion.

(Protip: use bat form during the day, the bat is invulnerable to the sun!)

The blood system was another unique component that I really enjoyed. At the start, you are running on frailed blood, which gives no added bonuses to the player, however, as you progress you can feed on NPCs allowing for you to acquire more refined blood. The blood has different types that grant the player different advantages. Among the different types, there are also different qualities of those types. With this system, the player can have tons of fun taking blood from the vast enemies in a chance to get a buff that may be useful for bosses or PvP. There is a sense of rarity to 100% blood of any type which is really nice. It adds an element of excitement and urgency when you do find it. Do you take it or do make it a prisoner? All of these components blend very well with the rest of the game, adding another seamless level of complexity to the game.

Boss design: 

I would say the boss design overall is great. There are lots of bosses that each test different aspects of your skill. With most bosses feeling absolutely unique and engaging. The environments that the bosses are in are often times quite interesting within themselves, and they allow the player to utilize them to gain an advantage over the boss, which for the most part, is overlooked in games in my personal opinion. 

Some of the bosses do seem to have ads in excess, and for those of you that don't know what ads are, they are minions/trash mobs. It can sometimes feel like the quality of a good boss fight is hampered by the fact that you are being dealt a bad hand at the expense of a trash mob(s). Personally it felt as though a few bosses could use AI improvement at the same time see a cutback on their ad spawning. 

One of the glaring issues with bosses, especially on increased difficulty mods, is the reliance on soloing bosses. Most bosses are designed for a solo, at most duo encounter. Beyond that, you are hampering your chances at successfully killing the boss immensely. For example, Nicholaus the Fallen is not feasible with more than 1 person due to the fact that the minion scaling, and HP scaling become completely absurd. This can take away from the enjoyment factor of playing with friends. And on competitive PvP servers almost guarantees that only 1 of your teammates is going to be doing the boss, which can be deemed boring.

World/Area Design:

I would give the map a solid score, too. I think overall the entire world immerses you quite well. There are tons of scenic vistas you'll be able to appreciate, in a world that was carefully curated, and designed with an emphasis on a good color palette, and enough gloom to make you feel like you're in a world run by vampires. The 4 zones (we'll exclude Gloomrot) all have really great differences, and are large enough for the player to explore for hours. Each bidding their own challenges. 

The material grind in each area can be relatively brutal, or easy depending on your sever settings. With a world filled with tons of unique items, everything has value, and I mean everything. One of my favorite aspects of this game is the the fact that every item is important in some way or another, so material grinding never feels pointless. Which in turn, raises the enjoyment factor. It's like getting shot with tiny bits of dopamine here and there as your playing, keeping you invested and interested the entire time. Which to me is an undervalued aspect of open-world games. Nothing feels worse than grinding for materials that ultimately don't matter down the line. 

I think the sheer size of the game is great, too. Each zone felt perfectly right in size, and never felt too bland or compact. The design plan was executed well and the picture is understood from the player's standpoint in terms of the geographical aspects.

Abilities/Weapons:

V Rising offers a large list of unique abilities that are interchangeable with one another, allowing the player to experiment with lots of different build ideas. This paired with other players playing alongside you, results in tons of combo potential and play-style potential in both the PvE and PvP environment. However, there are some things that should be mentioned.

A big issue with V Rising (pre-Gloomrot) is the obvious over-tuning of certain abilities. This results in what you'd expect. In a PvP setting especially, players opt to use the most powerful builds to maximize efficiency and their chance of winning. While that is natural, the game really only has a few notable builds, making the PvP combat feel incredibly stale after only a few sessions. This is less evident in PvE, so if you're not interested in PvP, you will likely not feel the effects of this.

The weapons in V Rising can best be described as simple. This is in no regard an insult, as the simplicity paired with the other factors of combat result in its seamless depth. With weapons having no more than 2 abilities, it allows for non-experienced and experienced players alike to enjoy and the learn the weapons without feeling overwhelmed. The abilities themselves are cool and unique as well. All of which fair well in both PvP and PvE environments. Each weapon really feels like it has value, and the added bonus of being able to seamlessly swap between them adds incredible depth without sacrificing simplicity. Again, add the fact that you will have friends with you, and then add spells, and you have a really nice blend for combat.

review:
Do you like vampires? 
Do you like survival games? 
Do you like survival games where you can be a vampire?
Well then do I have the game for you!

BUT WAIT, THERE’S MORE!

In this era of poor ports, Day One DLC, lockbox gambling, FOMO exploitation, Pay-2-Win mechanics, and predatory publishers, it’s incredibly important to have a developer who actually shows they give a shit not only about the quality of their product, but about their customers. 

Enter Stunlock Studios, a lovely group of folks who have developed a very simple premise into a game which was already quite enjoyable (eating up over 100 hours of my time) before the latest update. If they had never added anything else to it I would have still called it a game well worth my time and money, but then they announced their first major expansion.  

A lot of people asked “How can you have an expansion in an early access game?”  We all feared we were about to be charged an arm and a leg for some new DLC when the game wasn’t even officially released. Then the information arrived, this was a true EXPANSION OF THE GAME, not a DLC, not new content at a price, no, it was updated maps, updated weapons, an overhaul of systems under the hood, an entirely new method of building castles, a whole new string of bosses and a whole new area of the world, and it would cost us all… Nothing!  Nothing? NOTHING!

A free expansion of much needed Quality of Life updates alongside amazing new additions to the game play and aesthetic designs of the game. Then came the launch day for the new expansion and… It worked.  No server crashes. No hiccups. No false starts.  It worked from the word go!  It’s an S-Tier expansion with the devs being johnny on the spot whenever we players found bugs or issues. They’ve already done their first QoL patch for little snafus just two days later.

I cannot express how wonderful it is to have a dev team that’s response, cares about their player base, and was willing to take as much time as they needed to deliver an top notch expansion update to their game with as few bugs on release as humanly possible. 

Cheers to StunLock, cheers to V Rising, and cheers to proper commerce and interactions between product maker and product consumer. 

Go buy V Rising, you will have a wonderful time, and you’ll be buying a quality game at a reasonable price!

author: {'steamid': '76561198062633485', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 3323, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2986, 'playtime_at_review': 907, 'last_played': 1684548613}
review:
I want to like this game, and I'll even give it a positive review because I want to see it grow. The combat is fun and fluid, the mechanics are interesting, and the map is nice. But I don't know if I can recommend this game if you are a solo, especially if you're interested in PvP, which at it's core is what I believe this game was designed around. The resource grind is a bit slow, and craft times are annoying. But that's not even to mention other players.

If you deign to play on a PvP server, be prepared to lose every skirmish you get into, especially as a solo. Servers that are advertised as solo/duo often still have groups of 3+ running around, and with no way to report them or any admins, they go unpunished. Honestly the rat poly-morph should have been the first power you received because you cannot outrun them and you CERTAINLY cannot fight them, which leads me to my next topic.

Gear discrepancy is the most unbalanced I've ever seen in a survival game, but I guess that's the draw for a large amount of the player-base. Get geared and go grief lower levels to inflate your ego. It makes me wish the zones were segmented based on level (Perhaps with some kind of zone event or bounty system allowing access to the next zone?), but that would divide the already small player-base. You cannot run from higher level players because they have access to better mobility spells and a horse that is faster than the wolf form you start with. You cannot fight them because, true to the developer's name, they will stunlock you and kill you in 4-5 hits while you deal next to no damage what-so-ever. The only advice I can offer is stay OFF the main roads at ALL COSTS until you're confident you can fight them. Find other ways around the map, and rush for the rat poly-morph spell ASAP, it is the best hiding tool in the game. That and pray your base isn't found while you try to sleep or work. Even then finding a good location for your base is difficult, as most spots are taken in the starting zone and that seems to be where the higher level players patrol the most looking for easy kills. They will grief you, they will take your blueprints that they do not need just to deny you access to them, and they will raid your base regardless of what's inside.

As for the PvE, it's ight. Not hard though, at all. The only time I struggled was when a mob was much higher level than me, and even then it's doable. If you're ever close to dying just run away, most mobs won't be able to catch you. Bosses are kinda cool, but again not hard. The only stressful part in my experience is running back with all the loot in hopes of not finding another group of players. If you want a challenge go fight bosses when they're still a handful of levels above you I guess.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078170528', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4831, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 420, 'playtime_at_review': 4831, 'last_played': 1683571214}
review:
I am super impressed with the balance the devs have achieved in this game.  Especially because it has co-op functionality.
It's been a very long time since i played an open-world, objective based RPG, that did not feel in the least bit grindy.
Whether solo or with friends, every time I leave the castle, it feels like a little adventure. Prepare for the boss fight (the objective), get appropriately geared, (skills, pots, blood type) and head out. If you return successful, not only have you unlocked new skills and recipes, but you also always have a ton of mats to craft new stuff, as well as more of the old stuff. Very rarely will you need to go farming for specific mats, so long as you dont go full stealth and just go kill the boss and return. And preparing for a boss, or opening a new area, is also a rewarding task in itself. 

Excellent job devs. Well done. Cant wait for the DLC drop!

review:
It's just one of those games. I have over 200 hours played. So far I've played PVP on release and 2 PVE playthroughs, 2 months after release and now almost one year later. All playthroughs I had reached the maximum level gear and killed all bosses.

It's an interesting game to say the least. I love building in games in general so I was sold immediately.
I saw a lot of reviews mentioning the decay system and that it is horrible, which I see why they say that, At mid-end game all it takes is maybe 30 minutes of killing mobs to feed your castle to the max. On a level 2 Castle (which is so easy to get) it is about 5,5 days. At max lvl castle (Level 4) It's 12 days. Imo its not that bad. 

All in all I really like this game, It has decent mechanics when it comes to bosses, nothing over the top. 
The game can be difficult at times if you pull to much mobs so really, you can play however you want. 
Ez mode? Pull mobs one at a time. Up for a challenge? Just run in the camp without thinking. 

I dont know what i'm saying at this point. So really, the game is 20 buckeroos bro, give it a try :)

There are so many monsters and bosses, it seems like a never ending ride of challenging excitement and fun. author: {'steamid': '76561199243311073', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 2729, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 54, 'playtime_at_review': 2710, 'last_played': 1684394807}
review:
Okay, good game. However, there are a few things to note before purchasing this game.

1.) It is meant to be played cooperatively, so single players will want to modify the details and characteristics of their sole serve to make it less grindy.

2.) This game's controls, thou finicky, are relatively good but can be a bit of a issue for newer players.

3.) Bosses and enemies in this game can be very tricky for new players; and new players may wander into an area where higher level opponents will mop the floor with them.

4.) This point is more for the older players who purchased the bundle edition prior to the Gloomrot update. But the purchasing of the original bundle won't give you the new Gloomrot cosmetics for free. You need to purchase it, but it'll be at a 10% discount if you purchased the original bundle.

5.) This game is really what you make of it. It can be a building game for some, a multiplayer game to others, or a over-powered vampire lord simulation for another. 

6.) Frame rate issues can be a big issue and my computer froze upon changing the settings in options. So proceed with caution. 

7.) Be sure to adjust your graphical and game play settings prior to beginning a game. This is to ensure your computer functions normally and that the game is still playable without bricking your system.

Overall, is the game good? Yes! However, the beauty is in the eye of the beholder, so my opinion is not the end all be all for reviews. There are issues, but the developers are seemingly responsive and actively adding features players want in the game (multi-leveled bases for instance). All in all, I am mildly curious what is next to come.

author: {'steamid': '76561198065269138', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 21844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 2131, 'playtime_at_review': 21207, 'last_played': 1684544784}
review:
A must grab if you are into vampires, sandbox survivals and top-down fights. It's a quite unique mix to be fair, but it works really well imho.

Game was already providing great value for its price, but the recent Gloomrot update made it much better by adding QoL changes so much needed: not having to walk half map to bring a thrall back to your remote located base, more mats now can be moved through portals, more doable farming of certain mats in early/mid stages of the game (bone dust f.i), the skill revamp allowing for new fun builds, and a long list of other improvements you may not be able to tell if you didn't play before Gloomrot.

All that on top of the new content mentioned already in their site, which is also really cool (specially 3-floor castles for building fans) and felt polished so far.

Also, for those concerned, you can play Vrising solo, the game doesn't force you to be in party in order to do any content. With the new changes farming isn't even a chore anymore at any stage; not that I could tell at least. PVP is also fun, albeit I don't recommend it if you won't be able to play on a daily basis, kinda like any other pvp survival game.. multi-floor castles should also make raiding quite harder now, but idk.

Either way, absolutely recommended. Props to the Vrising team for their dedication, keep up the good job. Can't wait to see what you have in the store for us in the future :)

Build a big mansion, gather resources, craft items, fight bosses, cast spells, be a vampire.

Combat is solid, feels a bit like League of Legends with WASD movement.
You can turn down the grindyness of the vanilla game in the server settings, and I would recommended turning up resources/loot and decreasing crafting times.
Multi-story building really makes this game creatively fulfilling. Balconies and outlooks galore.

Unfortunately, you really need a dedicated server and some friends to get the most out of this game. I'm not sure I would want to play by myself for very long. Especially with the vanilla settings, this game can be incredibly grindy and tedious. However, anyone used to survival crafting games should feel right at home.

Other bosses like to go for long walks through the spooky forest just to come toss your unholy salad. My only complaint is that the controls do you no favors in combat. As far as base builders go, this one is aight. I haven't really got too far into it, but the castle looks clean af once you get going.

review:
V Rising is an incredible gaming experience that deserves nothing less than a glowing review. From the moment I stepped foot into this dark, immersive world, I was captivated by its unique concept and stunning visuals. As a vampire, you are tasked with rising from the grave and carving out your destiny in an unforgiving realm where darkness reigns supreme.

One of the first things that struck me about V Rising was its breathtaking graphics. The attention to detail in the environments, character models, and atmospheric effects is truly exceptional. The game effortlessly captures the eerie essence of being a creature of the night, with moonlit forests, gothic architecture, and haunting dungeons that create an immersive and atmospheric experience like no other.

The gameplay mechanics in V Rising are also praiseworthy. As you progress, you have the freedom to shape your vampire's abilities, choosing between different skill trees and playstyles. Whether you prefer to be a stealthy predator, a powerful sorcerer, or a fearsome warrior, the game accommodates various playstyles, allowing you to tailor your character to your preferred approach.

Another standout feature of V Rising is its robust and dynamic open-world. The map is vast and filled with diverse locations, each with its own secrets, challenges, and opportunities. From ancient crypts teeming with undead creatures to human settlements ripe for plunder, there is always something new to discover or conquer. After this most recent Gloomrot update, the world feels even more alive with more dense areas in terms of enemies and interest points.

Furthermore, the game's progression system is both rewarding and engaging. As you explore and complete quests, you gather resources that can be used to enhance your vampire's abilities, craft powerful weapons, and customize your lair. The sense of growth and accomplishment as you become more formidable is incredibly satisfying and keeps you motivated to push further into the darkness.

The cooperative gameplay elements in V Rising also deserve a mention. While you can certainly venture forth alone, the game truly shines when you team up with other players to tackle challenging bosses or engage in epic pvp battles. The sense of camaraderie and strategic coordination required to overcome formidable foes adds a layer of social interaction and excitement to the experience.

In conclusion, V Rising is a darkly beautiful, immersive, and exhilarating vampire-themed game that offers a fresh and captivating experience for players. Its stunning graphics, versatile gameplay mechanics, expansive open world, rewarding progression system and cooperative gameplay elements make it a true gem in the gaming world. Embrace your immortality and prepare to conquer the night in V Rising - you won't be disappointed!

review:
Terraria is a game that has stood the test of time and continues to captivate players with its unique blend of exploration, combat, and creativity. This 2D sandbox game has been a favorite among gamers since its initial release in 2011, and it's easy to see why.

The game offers a vast and dynamic world to explore, filled with a variety of biomes, enemies, and treasures to discover. From the underground depths of the earth to the heights of the sky, there's always something new and exciting to uncover.

But Terraria isn't just about exploring - it also offers a robust combat system that will challenge even the most seasoned players. With an array of weapons, armor, and accessories to choose from, players can tailor their playstyle to suit their preferences and take on the game's bosses with confidence.

And let's not forget about the game's creative potential. With a plethora of building materials and tools at your disposal, you can let your imagination run wild and create everything from towering castles to intricate pixel art. The possibilities are endless, and the satisfaction of seeing your creations come to life is truly rewarding.

But what sets Terraria apart from other games in its genre is the sense of community it fosters. Whether you're playing with friends or joining a public server, the game encourages collaboration and creativity. From building massive structures together to taking on the game's challenges as a team, Terraria is a game that brings people together.

In conclusion, Terraria is a game that has something for everyone. Its vast world, engaging combat, and creative potential make it a must-play for any fan of sandbox games. But it's the sense of community that really sets it apart and makes it a game that will continue to be enjoyed for years to come.

review: I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

review: When I was a child, my father never took an interest in my hobbies. He was always out, at work, or just doing ‘adult’ things. Due to this, I vowed that when I had kids, I would take an interest in their hobbies, whether they be sports, gaming, or whatever else! And that’s why I became a 45 year old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am the father to my son, Alfred, who is now 14. Recently, my son downloaded this game and in less than a week, he had already played for over 20 hours. This was devastating for me, as instead of bonding over ping pong, he was locked away in his room. As a result, I decided to make a Steam account, and get this game and take an interest in his hobbies, as my father had never done. I loaded into the game, and had no clue what to do, so I asked my son for help, and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it, as he hadn’t seemed this happy since we went rock climbing together in 2018. This game has ever since brought my son and I closer again, and now we spend time together on hobbies that I grew up with, such as fishing. This game reminded me that there’s fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both I and my son many happy memories.

review:
I think I'm gonna say it: I'm addicted.
I mean just look at my play time. That's not even too high in the grand scheme of things. I've seen people with up to 1,000.

If you love survival games, this game has got you covered. Countless hours of content await you here (trust me I'd know). The boss fights in this game are amazing as well, getting you to plan ahead and upgrade your gear before you can take them on. This game has SO many different things you can discover and provides a new experience every day. I'm still playing the first world I created at the time of writing this too.

I know it can't last forever but... it feels like it does. If you eventually run out of things to do on a world, there are different difficulties for you to try which change the game hugely and add tonnes of new loot (which will probably double my play time when I get to that haha). Oh by the way if you get stuck or want to craft something obscure that will take you 15 hours (looking at you Shellphone), check the Wiki! Its a great resource and there's a reason its built into the Title Screen.

review:
There is not a more worth it game to buy, I have a total of 1000 hours in Terraria (including tmod loader) and I can very easily say that this is one of favorite games of all time. You want an easy answer, buy the game, and here's why:

-The most replayable game on the market, I have done dozens of of playthroughs and it never gotten stale (partially from the class system, difficulty modifiers, and random world generation which can make each playthough different and interesting.) I'm gonna say it, its more replayable and definetly more bang for your buck than Minecraft, although those are just two factors.

-Cheap. 1/3 the price of great games like Minecraft while being just as good. You can make 10 bucks in 30 mins and though that hundreds of hours of fun.

-Multiplayer. Buy the game for a friend, you will have guaranteed fun, My first few playthoughs where with my siblings and friends and I still remember the fun we had.

-Modding. Finally getting tired of the game? Terrraria's modding scene is excellent and there as plenty of great Terraria mods worth more hours (may I suggest calamity ;)

so yeah the game is good

review: Terraria is a great game. The game is filled with content for various types of people. For example, there are countless bosses, items, enemies, and more for people who enjoy fighting in terraria, and thousands of blocks that can be used when building for more peaceful players. The bosses in this game are all very unique, difficult, and great. The game overall is very fun and is one of the best games to get a sense of adventure. There are classes within the game for if you want to be a melee based fighter, mage, ranged fighter, summoner, and more. There are countless options for what to do in the game, and you can almost never feel bored when playing. When you do beat the game, there are difficulties that can give harder bosses, new items, and a completely new and refreshing adventure. When you finish all of this, there are many great mods created by the community, making the game feel entirely different.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006621211', 'num_games_owned': 760, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1530467735}
review:
[h1]Regular Review[/h1]
[i]Fidel Dungeon Rescue[/i] is a rather clever, accessible roguelite turn-based puzzler.
Guide Fidel the corgi through various dungeon floors on a granny rescue mission. On his way Fidel levels up by beating enemies to gain additional HP, and picks up gold to power up special abilities. Usually you can't perfectly clear a level, so the game's all about maximizing gains within a limited (by a Spelunky-like ghost appearing on the floor if the player lingers for too long) time frame. There's a good variety of enemy types and objects, often requiring a special approach to tackle them. In a standard for some roguelites fashion you aren't provided with a lot of info on the game rules, instead discovering stuff through failure. It could've been annoying in a puzzle game, but, luckily, you can always undo and retrace your steps.

Level layouts are randomly generated, but follow strict templates, which somewhat harms replayability. So floor number 4 is always the "alien" level and so on. On the plus side, said templates often have unique mechanics, making a single run diverse.

Again, replayability appears to be [i]Fidel's[/i] weaker point, but there're hidden levels, characters and game modes to unlock, daily challenges, decent chunk of content overall. The graphics are cute, the soundtrack is actually great, play sessions are conveniently short. Overall, a pretty good indie title.

[h1]Daft Review[/h1] 
[b]Disclaimer: I was Fidel's stunt double during the making of the game. So when you see Fidel jumping through lava and eating spiders, yeah, that's actually me. [/b]

[i]Fidel Dungeon Rescue [/i] is an action-packed hardcorgi simulator. Battle ghouls, chase gnomes, play chess, fetch ball,  invade hell in this 100% authentic corgi experience. An amazing adventure. A normal day in a life of a corgi.
Ladies and gentlemen, you can play as a fat corgo. Or as a robo corg. OR as a zombie puppo. There's a dedicated bark button, incredible attention to crucial detail.
Family-friendly game: great way for your kids to learn about the sacrifices corgis make to protect and preserve humanity. 
Be a good dog, be a bad dog, be a dead dog, all major corgi archetypes are covered in this simulator, woofin' great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024965181', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1547237671}
review:
A very tight, very demanding puzzle-ish game that uses a simple, easily learnable set of mechanics to force you to make mind-destroyingly difficult decisions; getting near-perfect completions of most of the later floors requires you to think five steps ahead, but you don't have to be anywhere near perfect to progress to the next stage, which is a pretty lovely nugget of design. You gain items and health for doing earlier floors better, so performance on early floors affects your ability on later ones, and even when you can't figure out the perfect solution you're always pressured to do as well as you possibly can.

The randomly generated levels will occasionally throw you a floor you can wipe in one try out of instinct, and occasionally something that has you completely stuck, which can be demoralizing near the end of a good run. There's also a timer on each level, which I guess is there to make sure you can't be TOO cautious, but getting wrecked by a ghost when you're 3/4ths of the way through a tricky level can feel frustrating all the same. Despite these gripes, each individual puzzle is still a joy to solve. I don't know if I'll ever be able to 100% this game, but I find that just loading it up and playing a few floors is satisfying even when I don't get very far. I absolutely got the Tetris Effect going the first night I bought this, when I played it for an hour or so before bed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025196133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 4430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3609, 'last_played': 1608680712}
review:
Neat hybrid puzzle/roguelike game. A puppy is exploring a randomly generated, turn-based dungeon to rescue his gramma.  Unique to this game is that you have infinite "undos" but a two-minute time limit for each level which always pushes you forward.  Each level is a very compelling logic puzzle which can seem impossible at first but is almost always solvable.  

Completion of the main game unlocks an additional 10-level "extra-hard" dungeon; two "puzzle-mode" dungeons; a 4-level "speed run" dungeon, a daily challege mode, and more.  For $10, there's a lot of content here that keeps me coming back.

review:
I don't usally leave reviews, but this game is magic. Classic line drawing mechanic, combined with (mostly) stationary enemies and the "three-in-a-row" bonus somehow gave birth to a super compelling experience. A great example of how the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.

The enemies are interesting and intuitive; you pick up on their nuances quite naturally without any tiresome hand-holding. 

I thin it's a game you really have to try for yourself. I watched Northernlion's playthrough on YouTube and wasn't that impressed, but decided to get the game anyway. 15 mins in and I was hooked. Initially I was a little put off by the time pressure, but after awhile I began to appreciate the tension it provided. The game is not about finding the perfect solution(which often gets tedious in my opinion), and the time pressure just encourages you to move things along with a good enough solution.

Also, I'm happily exploring secrets.

Overall, highly recommended.

It's worth the money!

author: {'steamid': '76561198008561178', 'num_games_owned': 50, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3020, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1253, 'last_played': 1543032800}
review:
The best game that I've played in quite a long time.  A masterpiece of micro-design, with an insane amount of polish on every corner.

It's a "small" game, but so deep that it takes quite a long time to work your way through it.  And just when you think you're done, a whole new layer unfolds for you.

I just finished it, 15 hours in, but there are still a few loose ends left to tie up.

Also, it takes quite a while to understand all the nuances that are present in even the earliest levels.  But you can still make your way through them without full mastery.  I recall a gradual process of getting it more and more on each pass through.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978623302', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1421, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 814, 'last_played': 1584127323}
review:
This is one of the best puzzle game I've played in a long time. Design is simple, deep, full of surprise. 
The game doesn't hand hold you and it is pretty good at conveying its rules in a natural manner.

I find the music fantastic and to be perfect fit (rather unexpected for a puzzle game!), graphics are charming, the interaction are smooth and reactive, the effects and feedback are just the right amount of juicy. 

I guess it is more approachable than a game like The Witness (which I also loved but I think The Witness might be more overwhelming for many types of players? Just guessing).

Being able to play for short period of time is amazing, although I have to admit the "one more go" factor made me spend way too much time on it already!

review:
I'm not sure if the term rogue-lite applies here but there is definitely a random element to the game. At it's heart Fidel Dungeon Rescue is a puzzle game, a very good puzzle game, It puts a board in front of you allow you to attack it as you see fit. review:
I got a coupon for this game because I own Jonathan Blow's 'The Witness'. Jonathan Blow is credited in this game as one of 'The Elders', so I imagine that has something to do with the gameplay similarity between the two games.

I bought the game on a whim because of the coupon, and I've been pleasantly surprised. The graphics are wonderfully well done. The sound design and music are really great too. The mechanics are easy to learn, but tricky to master.

Although the surface level format of the gameplay is wildly different, Fidel has a strange amount of similarity to The Witness (in a good way). If you are a fan of those types of puzzles, but also want a game that will simultaneously scratch your dungeon-crawling itch, then this game is a good buy!

review: Fidel Dungeon Rescue is a really clever roguelite puzzle game, or maybe a puzzle game disguised as a roguelite? Just like other roguelites, it's permadeath and randomly generated levels crawling in enemies, but the true challenge isn't getting to the exit but finding the most optimal path to get there, which is where the puzzle aspect comes in. To survive the challenges at the end of the game, you've got to make sure you get as much XP as possible, which means coming up with a winding path through each level that kills as many enemies as possible and gets extra combo XP for consecutive kills. Thankfully, this is aided by the ability to undo your moves, so you can experiment and compare different routes, trying to balance combos, health, and the need to not cross over your own path. The game doesn't really explain anything, but with careful observation you'll quickly pick up on the rules and how to beat each enemy type (Don't forget about barking though! It's useful for identifying mimics and changing the direction that turtles face).

author: {'steamid': '76561198004565666', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 268, 'playtime_forever': 3667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 816, 'last_played': 1675911646}
review:
This is sort of a prickly game, but every aspect of it is designed perfectly for what they were trying to do. It's a roguelike puzzle-game, with the focus on finding a way to maximize XP in ecah level by carefully plotting a path through enemies+items. It requires you to really engage with every puzzle if you want to win the game, so it may not be for everyone.

Game mechanics are all simple and self-explanatory (in fact there's almost no text except for menus), but they combine to make very tricky puzzles. There's a good variety of enemies, introduced at a steady pace, who all bring a creative twist that you must account for.

The difficulty is very high, demanding you do well on every level or you won't be able to beat the later ones (especially the brutal boss levels).

The game also has a great soundtrack+aesthetics, and lots of neat extra modes you unlock once you beat the main dungeon once. (There's unlockable characters with new mechanics, hand-crafted puzzles, daily challenges, a second dungeon that functions as hard mode, another short bonus dungeon, and more). So even though the main quest isn't that long there's plenty of replay potential.

I literally cannot think of a single thing I can point to as a flaw. It's not necessarily my favorite game ever, but it knows what it wants to be and every detail is perfect for getting it there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026954039', 'num_games_owned': 533, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 2376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1910, 'last_played': 1522717923}
review:
Okay, so I haven't beaten this yet, but it's really good.

Puzzle-crawler is actually a very apt descriptor of Fidel Dungeon Rescue. If you like either of those types of games, you're in for a treat. Fidel's design is simple, devious, and very satisfying. The art, sound, and gameplay all form a very coherent package: short and sweet, and ridiculously replayable. You may not understand what you're doing the first 10 to 15 runs, but then the game's design begins to reveal itself. That's when Fidel gets its hooks into you. I might come back to this review. I just urge you to give this a try if it piques your interest.

Edit: It's still good, actually it's better.

review:
Fidel dungeon rescue is a great example of an underated game, it's amazing! Fantastic! And it's shocking that not that many people have heard of it. The first time I played through it, I found the game to be a little too unforgiving, 9 times out of 10 I wouldn't die from a mistake I made, but from moving the wrong way by accident...But thanks to the update, the game is less unforgiving, there's loads of new content, bug fixes, and little things that were polished up, like some of the animations, effects, and even gameplay.

I'd say it's totally worth the price, I thought it was high at first, especially for the game before the update, but now it's a better match for the price. I definitly recommend picking this up if a rogue-like puzzle game sounds fun to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006621211', 'num_games_owned': 760, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 195, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 195, 'last_played': 1530467735}
review:
[h1]Regular Review[/h1]
[i]Fidel Dungeon Rescue[/i] is a rather clever, accessible roguelite turn-based puzzler.
Guide Fidel the corgi through various dungeon floors on a granny rescue mission. On his way Fidel levels up by beating enemies to gain additional HP, and picks up gold to power up special abilities. Usually you can't perfectly clear a level, so the game's all about maximizing gains within a limited (by a Spelunky-like ghost appearing on the floor if the player lingers for too long) time frame. There's a good variety of enemy types and objects, often requiring a special approach to tackle them. In a standard for some roguelites fashion you aren't provided with a lot of info on the game rules, instead discovering stuff through failure. It could've been annoying in a puzzle game, but, luckily, you can always undo and retrace your steps.

Level layouts are randomly generated, but follow strict templates, which somewhat harms replayability. So floor number 4 is always the "alien" level and so on. On the plus side, said templates often have unique mechanics, making a single run diverse.

Again, replayability appears to be [i]Fidel's[/i] weaker point, but there're hidden levels, characters and game modes to unlock, daily challenges, decent chunk of content overall. The graphics are cute, the soundtrack is actually great, play sessions are conveniently short. Overall, a pretty good indie title.

[h1]Daft Review[/h1] 
[b]Disclaimer: I was Fidel's stunt double during the making of the game. So when you see Fidel jumping through lava and eating spiders, yeah, that's actually me. [/b]

[i]Fidel Dungeon Rescue [/i] is an action-packed hardcorgi simulator. Battle ghouls, chase gnomes, play chess, fetch ball,  invade hell in this 100% authentic corgi experience. An amazing adventure. A normal day in a life of a corgi.
Ladies and gentlemen, you can play as a fat corgo. Or as a robo corg. OR as a zombie puppo. There's a dedicated bark button, incredible attention to crucial detail.
Family-friendly game: great way for your kids to learn about the sacrifices corgis make to protect and preserve humanity. 
Be a good dog, be a bad dog, be a dead dog, all major corgi archetypes are covered in this simulator, woofin' great.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024965181', 'num_games_owned': 176, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 1618, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 476, 'last_played': 1547237671}
review:
A very tight, very demanding puzzle-ish game that uses a simple, easily learnable set of mechanics to force you to make mind-destroyingly difficult decisions; getting near-perfect completions of most of the later floors requires you to think five steps ahead, but you don't have to be anywhere near perfect to progress to the next stage, which is a pretty lovely nugget of design. You gain items and health for doing earlier floors better, so performance on early floors affects your ability on later ones, and even when you can't figure out the perfect solution you're always pressured to do as well as you possibly can.

The randomly generated levels will occasionally throw you a floor you can wipe in one try out of instinct, and occasionally something that has you completely stuck, which can be demoralizing near the end of a good run. There's also a timer on each level, which I guess is there to make sure you can't be TOO cautious, but getting wrecked by a ghost when you're 3/4ths of the way through a tricky level can feel frustrating all the same. Despite these gripes, each individual puzzle is still a joy to solve. I don't know if I'll ever be able to 100% this game, but I find that just loading it up and playing a few floors is satisfying even when I don't get very far. I absolutely got the Tetris Effect going the first night I bought this, when I played it for an hour or so before bed.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025196133', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 4430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3609, 'last_played': 1608680712}
review:
Neat hybrid puzzle/roguelike game. A puppy is exploring a randomly generated, turn-based dungeon to rescue his gramma.  Unique to this game is that you have infinite "undos" but a two-minute time limit for each level which always pushes you forward.  Each level is a very compelling logic puzzle which can seem impossible at first but is almost always solvable.  

Completion of the main game unlocks an additional 10-level "extra-hard" dungeon; two "puzzle-mode" dungeons; a 4-level "speed run" dungeon, a daily challege mode, and more.  For $10, there's a lot of content here that keeps me coming back.

review:
I don't usally leave reviews, but this game is magic. Classic line drawing mechanic, combined with (mostly) stationary enemies and the "three-in-a-row" bonus somehow gave birth to a super compelling experience. A great example of how the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.

The enemies are interesting and intuitive; you pick up on their nuances quite naturally without any tiresome hand-holding. 

I thin it's a game you really have to try for yourself. I watched Northernlion's playthrough on YouTube and wasn't that impressed, but decided to get the game anyway. 15 mins in and I was hooked. Initially I was a little put off by the time pressure, but after awhile I began to appreciate the tension it provided. The game is not about finding the perfect solution(which often gets tedious in my opinion), and the time pressure just encourages you to move things along with a good enough solution.

Also, I'm happily exploring secrets.

Overall, highly recommended.

review:
The best game that I've played in quite a long time.  A masterpiece of micro-design, with an insane amount of polish on every corner.

It's a "small" game, but so deep that it takes quite a long time to work your way through it.  And just when you think you're done, a whole new layer unfolds for you.

I just finished it, 15 hours in, but there are still a few loose ends left to tie up.

review:
I'm not sure if the term rogue-lite applies here but there is definitely a random element to the game. At it's heart Fidel Dungeon Rescue is a puzzle game, a very good puzzle game, It puts a board in front of you allow you to attack it as you see fit. I have beaten the game multiple times but still feel compelled to play more of it. That is the mark of a good game for me, and that is why I am recommending it.

review:
I got a coupon for this game because I own Jonathan Blow's 'The Witness'. Jonathan Blow is credited in this game as one of 'The Elders', so I imagine that has something to do with the gameplay similarity between the two games.

I bought the game on a whim because of the coupon, and I've been pleasantly surprised. The graphics are wonderfully well done. The sound design and music are really great too. The mechanics are easy to learn, but tricky to master.

Although the surface level format of the gameplay is wildly different, Fidel has a strange amount of similarity to The Witness (in a good way). If you are a fan of those types of puzzles, but also want a game that will simultaneously scratch your dungeon-crawling itch, then this game is a good buy!

review: Fidel Dungeon Rescue is a really clever roguelite puzzle game, or maybe a puzzle game disguised as a roguelite? Just like other roguelites, it's permadeath and randomly generated levels crawling in enemies, but the true challenge isn't getting to the exit but finding the most optimal path to get there, which is where the puzzle aspect comes in. To survive the challenges at the end of the game, you've got to make sure you get as much XP as possible, which means coming up with a winding path through each level that kills as many enemies as possible and gets extra combo XP for consecutive kills. Thankfully, this is aided by the ability to undo your moves, so you can experiment and compare different routes, trying to balance combos, health, and the need to not cross over your own path. The game doesn't really explain anything, but with careful observation you'll quickly pick up on the rules and how to beat each enemy type (Don't forget about barking though! It's useful for identifying mimics and changing the direction that turtles face).

author: {'steamid': '76561198004565666', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 268, 'playtime_forever': 3667, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 816, 'last_played': 1675911646}
review:
This is sort of a prickly game, but every aspect of it is designed perfectly for what they were trying to do. It's a roguelike puzzle-game, with the focus on finding a way to maximize XP in ecah level by carefully plotting a path through enemies+items. It requires you to really engage with every puzzle if you want to win the game, so it may not be for everyone.

Game mechanics are all simple and self-explanatory (in fact there's almost no text except for menus), but they combine to make very tricky puzzles. There's a good variety of enemies, introduced at a steady pace, who all bring a creative twist that you must account for.

The difficulty is very high, demanding you do well on every level or you won't be able to beat the later ones (especially the brutal boss levels).

The game also has a great soundtrack+aesthetics, and lots of neat extra modes you unlock once you beat the main dungeon once. (There's unlockable characters with new mechanics, hand-crafted puzzles, daily challenges, a second dungeon that functions as hard mode, another short bonus dungeon, and more). So even though the main quest isn't that long there's plenty of replay potential.

I literally cannot think of a single thing I can point to as a flaw. It's not necessarily my favorite game ever, but it knows what it wants to be and every detail is perfect for getting it there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198026954039', 'num_games_owned': 533, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 2376, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1910, 'last_played': 1522717923}
review:
Okay, so I haven't beaten this yet, but it's really good.

Puzzle-crawler is actually a very apt descriptor of Fidel Dungeon Rescue. If you like either of those types of games, you're in for a treat. Fidel's design is simple, devious, and very satisfying. The art, sound, and gameplay all form a very coherent package: short and sweet, and ridiculously replayable. You may not understand what you're doing the first 10 to 15 runs, but then the game's design begins to reveal itself. That's when Fidel gets its hooks into you. I might come back to this review. I just urge you to give this a try if it piques your interest.

Edit: It's still good, actually it's better.

It took me around 8 hours to complete the game in its current state, although I haven't done the extended challenges. There's definitely room for some more mechanics and ideas to be implemented, and I hope the devs are still planning on releasing a bit more content.

review:
Fidel dungeon rescue is a great example of an underated game, it's amazing! Fantastic! And it's shocking that not that many people have heard of it. The first time I played through it, I found the game to be a little too unforgiving, 9 times out of 10 I wouldn't die from a mistake I made, but from moving the wrong way by accident...But thanks to the update, the game is less unforgiving, there's loads of new content, bug fixes, and little things that were polished up, like some of the animations, effects, and even gameplay.

I'd say it's totally worth the price, I thought it was high at first, especially for the game before the update, but now it's a better match for the price. I definitly recommend picking this up if a rogue-like puzzle game sounds fun to you.
